results.title: Oscillators
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Radio Technician Training”.
Explains the basic principles of electronic oscillation and variations in oscillations are studied; functioning of a common circuit and tank circuit are explained by means of animation.

results.title: Now or never
results.creator_credit: Linda Harrar, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 10 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
The concluding episode of this series focuses on individuals and organisations who are fighting for the survival of the planet. It emphasises that whilst international treaties and organisations play a major role, individuals can also make a significant difference. The need for cooperation between all nations, rich and poor, has never been more urgent as “we need to make peace with each other in order to make peace with nature”. Narrated by Karina Kelly. A teacher’s guide accompanies the video.

results.title: Race to save the planet
results.creator_credit: John Angier, Carol Lynn Dornbrand, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description: A series of programs on the global environmental crisis facing us all. Each program takes an in-depth look at the relationships between human society and the earth’s natural resources, focusing on solutions, constructive ideas and new approaches from all over the world. Each video is accompanied by teacher’s notes.

results.title: It needs political decisions
results.creator_credit: Vivian Ducat, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 9 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the role that governments can play in protecting the environment. In Zimbabwe, President Mugabe talks about the importance of education and of balancing people’s needs against those of the environment. In Thailand, as in Zimbabwe, population growth has been a major problem, and government birth control programs have played an important role in reducing this growth. Popular protest also plays a role in influencing governments, as in Sweden which now has a nuclear ban forced by the people, but care should also be taken that the political decisions made have taken every possible outcome into consideration. Narrated by Karina Kelly. A teacher’s book accompanies the video.

results.title: Waste not want not
results.creator_credit: Vivian Ducat, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 8 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines tales of garbage barges, toxic dumping, overflowing landfills and sewage polluting coastal waters. But it also tells of some imaginative and economically viable ways of not only disposing of waste materials, but also of making use of them for the benefit of the local communities who produce them. Narrated by Karina Kelly.

results.title: Save the Earth, feed the world
results.creator_credit: Edwin Scragg, Veronica Young, Jane West, Andrew Liebman, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 7 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines world food production and the challenge of feeding a growing population. The program discusses the environmental damage caused by conventional, intensive farming in both industrial and developing countries and the worldwide movement to replace conventional methods with low-input, sustainable agricultural practices. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: More for less
results.creator_credit: Marty Ostrow, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 6 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
A series of case studies which show how fossil fuels can either be used more efficiently or replaced altogether by alternative energy sources. The program stresses, however, that unless the alternatives are shown to be economically advantageous, no matter how environmentally desirable renewable energy sources are, they will not replace fossil fuels in the near future. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: Remnants of Eden
results.creator_credit: Christopher McCullough, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 5 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines the possibility that this generation may preside over a biological mass extinction of half the species on earth today. It addresses the delicate balance of protecting life’s diversity whilst managing the needs of growing human populations. Examples are taken from Kenya, United States, Thailand, Oman and Costa Rica. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.

results.title: In the name of progress
results.creator_credit: Katherine Carpenter, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
results.brief_description:
Episode number 4 of Series “Race to save the planet”.
This program examines well-intended development projects in the third world and the environmental disasters that resulted, and questions whether environmental protection and economic development are inherently in conflict. It profiles ‘sustainable development’ alternatives in Brazil and India. Narrated by Karina Kelly. Teacher’s notes accompany the video.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Katherine Carpenter, Film Australia, Chedd-Angier Productions and WGBH (Boston)
